acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Not classified from its 24h-EC50 = 129.5 mg/L for Crustacea (Daphnia magna) (AQUIRE, 2010).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of 0.141 mL/kg (134 mg/kg) for rabbits (HSDB (2003)), the substance was classified into Category 2.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data. As relevant information, the test substance was administered to rats for 136 minutes (100% mortality) or 68 minutes (no mortality) at saturated vapour pressure concentration and LT50 was determined to be 96 minutes (HSDB (2003)).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: From a report that mortality was 5/5 at 1.25 mL/kg (1188 mg/kg) and 5/6 at 0.625 mL/kg (594 mg/kg) in a rat test (HSDB (2003)), the substance corresponds to the category with higher hazard than Category 4. However, a dermal LD50 value is 134 mg/kg. Since the oral absorption was estimated to be similar or greater than the dermal absorption, the substance was classified into Category 3 exceptionally. Also, it could be classified into Category 2.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Not classified since its acute toxicity is Not classified and it is not non-water soluble from water solubility = 130,000 mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2010).

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified into Category 3 since flash point 51 degC (closed-cup) (UNRTDG (15th, 2007)) is >=23 degC and <=60 degC. The substance is classified into Class 3, PG III in UNRTDG.

organic_peroxides.rationale: Organic compounds containing no bivalent -O-O- structure

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: The substance is an organic compound containing oxygen (but not fluorine or chlorine) which is chemically bonded only to carbon or hydrogen.

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Auto-ignition point is 375 degC (GESTIS (access on Aug. 2009)) exceeding 70 degC.

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on a result in an eye irritation test using 3 rabbits (OECD TG405 (GLP)) where irritation index MMAS (correspond to AOI) was 21.7, corneal opacities and conjunctivae redness were observed in 1/3 rabbit until day 7 after application and the effects were completely reversible on day 14 (ECETOC TR48 (1998)), the substance was classified into Category 2.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on a report that no irritation was noted on 4 rabbits and moderate capillary injection was noted on one rabbit in a primary dermal irritation test where either undiluted substance or diluted substance (10, 1, 0.1, 0.01%) was applied in 0.01 mL amounts to the skin of 5 rabbits (HSDB (2003)), the substance was classified as "Not classified".

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: In a rat oral test at 0.625 mL/kg (594 mg/kg) and 1.25 mL/kg (1188 mg/kg) which are within the guidance value range for Category 2, toxic signs such as sluggish, unsteady gait and convulsions were observed and gross pathology revealed mottled red and tan livers and pale kidneys. Almost all rats died at 0.625 - 2.5 mL/kg (594 - 2376 mg/kg). In a rabbit dermal test, at 0.2 mL/kg (190 mg/kg) and higher doses which are within the guidance value range for Category 1, lacrimation and convulsions were observed and gross pathology revealed mottled red and light tan livers and pale kidneys. The LD50 was determined to be 0.141 mL/kg (134 mg/kg). The animals died at dose levels within the guidance value ranges for both oral and dermal routes. This information are reported in a document in List 2. Neurologic symptoms such as convulsion were observed with both the oral and dermal routes. The substance was classified into Category 2 (central nervous system) (HSDB (2003)).
